speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: The Tomb of the ANDRONICI appearing; the Tribunes  and Senators aloft. Enter, below, from one side,  SATURNINUS and his Followers; and, from the other side, BASSIANUS and his Followers; with drum and colours

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Noble patricians, patrons of my right,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Defend the justice of my cause with arms,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And, countrymen, my loving followers,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Plead my successive title with your swords:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I am his first-born son, that was the last

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That wore the imperial diadem of Rome;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Then let my father's honours live in me,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Nor wrong mine age with this indignity.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Romans, friends, followers, favorers of my right,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: If ever Bassianus, Caesar's son,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Were gracious in the eyes of royal Rome,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Keep then this passage to the Capitol

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And suffer not dishonour to approach

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: The imperial seat, to virtue consecrate,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: To justice, continence and nobility;

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: But let desert in pure election shine,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And, Romans, fight for freedom in your choice.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Enter MARCUS ANDRONICUS, aloft, with the crown

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Princes, that strive by factions and by friends

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ambitiously for rule and empery,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Know that the people of Rome, for whom we stand

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A special party, have, by common voice,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In election for the Roman empery,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Chosen Andronicus, surnamed Pius

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For many good and great deserts to Rome:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A nobler man, a braver warrior,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lives not this day within the city walls:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: He by the senate is accit'd home

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: From weary wars against the barbarous Goths;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That, with his sons, a terror to our foes,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hath yoked a nation strong, train'd up in arms.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ten years are spent since first he undertook

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This cause of Rome and chastised with arms

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Our enemies' pride: five times he hath return'd

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Bleeding to Rome, bearing his valiant sons

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In coffins from the field;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And now at last, laden with horror's spoils,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Returns the good Andronicus to Rome,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Renowned Titus, flourishing in arms.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Let us entreat, by honour of his name,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whom worthily you would have now succeed.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And in the Capitol and senate's right,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whom you pretend to honour and adore,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That you withdraw you and abate your strength;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Dismiss your followers and, as suitors should,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Plead your deserts in peace and humbleness.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: How fair the tribune speaks to calm my thoughts!

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Marcus Andronicus, so I do ally

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: In thy uprightness and integrity,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And so I love and honour thee and thine,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Thy noble brother Titus and his sons,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And her to whom my thoughts are humbled all,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Gracious Lavinia, Rome's rich ornament,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: That I will here dismiss my loving friends,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And to my fortunes and the people's favor

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Commit my cause in balance to be weigh'd.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Exeunt the followers of BASSIANUS

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Friends, that have been thus forward in my right,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I thank you all and here dismiss you all,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And to the love and favor of my country

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Commit myself, my person and the cause.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Exeunt the followers of SATURNINUS

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Rome, be as just and gracious unto me

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: As I am confident and kind to thee.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Open the gates, and let me in.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Tribunes, and me, a poor competitor.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Flourish. SATURNINUS and BASSIANUS go up into the Capitol

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Enter a Captain

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Romans, make way: the good Andronicus.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Patron of virtue, Rome's best champion,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Successful in the battles that he fights,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: With honour and with fortune is return'd

speaker: Captain
text_entry: From where he circumscribed with his sword,

speaker: Captain
text_entry: And brought to yoke, the enemies of Rome.

speaker: Captain
text_entry: Drums and trumpets sounded. Enter MARTIUS and  MUTIUS; After them, two Men bearing a coffin  covered with black; then LUCIUS and QUINTUS. After  them, TITUS ANDRONICUS; and then TAMORA, with  ALARBUS, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, AARON, and other Goths,  prisoners; Soldiers and people following. The Bearers set down the coffin, and TITUS speaks

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hail, Rome, victorious in thy mourning weeds!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lo, as the bark, that hath discharged her fraught,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Returns with precious jading to the bay

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: From whence at first she weigh'd her anchorage,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Cometh Andronicus, bound with laurel boughs,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To re-salute his country with his tears,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tears of true joy for his return to Rome.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thou great defender of this Capitol,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Stand gracious to the rites that we intend!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Romans, of five and twenty valiant sons,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Half of the number that King Priam had,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Behold the poor remains, alive and dead!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These that survive let Rome reward with love;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These that I bring unto their latest home,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: With burial amongst their ancestors:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here Goths have given me leave to sheathe my sword.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Titus, unkind and careless of thine own,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why suffer'st thou thy sons, unburied yet,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To hover on the dreadful shore of Styx?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Make way to lay them by their brethren.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The tomb is opened

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: There greet in silence, as the dead are wont,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And sleep in peace, slain in your country's wars!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O sacred receptacle of my joys,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sweet cell of virtue and nobility,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: How many sons of mine hast thou in store,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That thou wilt never render to me more!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Give us the proudest prisoner of the Goths,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That we may hew his limbs, and on a pile

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Ad manes fratrum sacrifice his flesh,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Before this earthy prison of their bones;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That so the shadows be not unappeased,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Nor we disturb'd with prodigies on earth.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I give him you, the noblest that survives,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The eldest son of this distressed queen.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Stay, Roman brethren! Gracious conqueror,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Victorious Titus, rue the tears I shed,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: A mother's tears in passion for her son:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And if thy sons were ever dear to thee,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: O, think my son to be as dear to me!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Sufficeth not that we are brought to Rome,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To beautify thy triumphs and return,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Captive to thee and to thy Roman yoke,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But must my sons be slaughter'd in the streets,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For valiant doings in their country's cause?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: O, if to fight for king and commonweal

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Were piety in thine, it is in these.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Andronicus, stain not thy tomb with blood:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Wilt thou draw near the nature of the gods?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Draw near them then in being merciful:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Sweet mercy is nobility's true badge:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Thrice noble Titus, spare my first-born son.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Patient yourself, madam, and pardon me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These are their brethren, whom you Goths beheld

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Alive and dead, and for their brethren slain

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Religiously they ask a sacrifice:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To this your son is mark'd, and die he must,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To appease their groaning shadows that are gone.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Away with him! and make a fire straight;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And with our swords, upon a pile of wood,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let's hew his limbs till they be clean consumed.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exeunt LUCIUS, QUINTUS, MARTIUS, and MUTIUS, with ALARBUS

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: O cruel, irreligious piety!

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Was ever Scythia half so barbarous?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Oppose not Scythia to ambitious Rome.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Alarbus goes to rest; and we survive

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To tremble under Titus' threatening looks.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Then, madam, stand resolved, but hope withal

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: The self-same gods that arm'd the Queen of Troy

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: With opportunity of sharp revenge

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Upon the Thracian tyrant in his tent,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: May favor Tamora, the Queen of Goths--

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: When Goths were Goths and Tamora was queen--

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To quit the bloody wrongs upon her foes.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS, QUINTUS, MARTIUS and MUTIUS, with their swords bloody

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: See, lord and father, how we have perform'd

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Our Roman rites: Alarbus' limbs are lopp'd,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And entrails feed the sacrificing fire,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Whose smoke, like incense, doth perfume the sky.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Remaineth nought, but to inter our brethren,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And with loud 'larums welcome them to Rome.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Let it be so; and let Andronicus

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Make this his latest farewell to their souls.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Trumpets sounded, and the coffin laid in the tomb

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In peace and honour rest you here, my sons;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rome's readiest champions, repose you here in rest,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Secure from worldly chances and mishaps!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here lurks no treason, here no envy swells,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here grow no damned grudges; here are no storms,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No noise, but silence and eternal sleep:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In peace and honour rest you here, my sons!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter LAVINIA

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: In peace and honour live Lord Titus long;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: My noble lord and father, live in fame!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Lo, at this tomb my tributary tears

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: I render, for my brethren's obsequies;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And at thy feet I kneel, with tears of joy,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Shed on the earth, for thy return to Rome:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, bless me here with thy victorious hand,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Whose fortunes Rome's best citizens applaud!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kind Rome, that hast thus lovingly reserved

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The cordial of mine age to glad my heart!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lavinia, live; outlive thy father's days,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And fame's eternal date, for virtue's praise!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter, below, MARCUS ANDRONICUS and Tribunes; re-enter SATURNINUS and BASSIANUS, attended

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Long live Lord Titus, my beloved brother,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Gracious triumpher in the eyes of Rome!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thanks, gentle tribune, noble brother Marcus.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And welcome, nephews, from successful wars,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You that survive, and you that sleep in fame!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Fair lords, your fortunes are alike in all,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That in your country's service drew your swords:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But safer triumph is this funeral pomp,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That hath aspired to Solon's happiness

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And triumphs over chance in honour's bed.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Titus Andronicus, the people of Rome,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whose friend in justice thou hast ever been,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Send thee by me, their tribune and their trust,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This palliament of white and spotless hue;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And name thee in election for the empire,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: With these our late-deceased emperor's sons:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Be candidatus then, and put it on,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And help to set a head on headless Rome.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A better head her glorious body fits

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Than his that shakes for age and feebleness:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What should I don this robe, and trouble you?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Be chosen with proclamations to-day,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To-morrow yield up rule, resign my life,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And set abroad new business for you all?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rome, I have been thy soldier forty years,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And led my country's strength successfully,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And buried one and twenty valiant sons,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Knighted in field, slain manfully in arms,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In right and service of their noble country

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Give me a staff of honour for mine age,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But not a sceptre to control the world:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Upright he held it, lords, that held it last.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Titus, thou shalt obtain and ask the empery.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Proud and ambitious tribune, canst thou tell?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Patience, Prince Saturninus.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Romans, do me right:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Patricians, draw your swords: and sheathe them not

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Till Saturninus be Rome's emperor.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Andronicus, would thou wert shipp'd to hell,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Rather than rob me of the people's hearts!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Proud Saturnine, interrupter of the good

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That noble-minded Titus means to thee!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Content thee, prince; I will restore to thee

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The people's hearts, and wean them from themselves.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Andronicus, I do not flatter thee,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: But honour thee, and will do till I die:

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: My faction if thou strengthen with thy friends,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: I will most thankful be; and thanks to men

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Of noble minds is honourable meed.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: People of Rome, and people's tribunes here,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I ask your voices and your suffrages:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will you bestow them friendly on Andronicus?

speaker: Tribunes
text_entry: To gratify the good Andronicus,

speaker: Tribunes
text_entry: And gratulate his safe return to Rome,

speaker: Tribunes
text_entry: The people will accept whom he admits.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tribunes, I thank you: and this suit I make,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That you create your emperor's eldest son,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lord Saturnine; whose virtues will, I hope,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Reflect on Rome as Titan's rays on earth,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And ripen justice in this commonweal:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then, if you will elect by my advice,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Crown him and say 'Long live our emperor!'

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: With voices and applause of every sort,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Patricians and plebeians, we create

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lord Saturninus Rome's great emperor,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And say 'Long live our Emperor Saturnine!'

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A long flourish till they come down

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Titus Andronicus, for thy favors done

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: To us in our election this day,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I give thee thanks in part of thy deserts,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And will with deeds requite thy gentleness:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And, for an onset, Titus, to advance

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thy name and honourable family,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Lavinia will I make my empress,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Rome's royal mistress, mistress of my heart,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And in the sacred Pantheon her espouse:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Tell me, Andronicus, doth this motion please thee?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: It doth, my worthy lord; and in this match

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I hold me highly honour'd of your grace:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And here in sight of Rome to Saturnine,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: King and commander of our commonweal,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The wide world's emperor, do I consecrate

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My sword, my chariot and my prisoners;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Presents well worthy Rome's imperial lord:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Receive them then, the tribute that I owe,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Mine honour's ensigns humbled at thy feet.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thanks, noble Titus, father of my life!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: How proud I am of thee and of thy gifts

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Rome shall record, and when I do forget

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: The least of these unspeakable deserts,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Romans, forget your fealty to me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: [To TAMORA]  Now, madam, are you prisoner to

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: an emperor;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To him that, for your honour and your state,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will use you nobly and your followers.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: A goodly lady, trust me; of the hue

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That I would choose, were I to choose anew.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Clear up, fair queen, that cloudy countenance:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Though chance of war hath wrought this change of cheer,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thou comest not to be made a scorn in Rome:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Princely shall be thy usage every way.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Rest on my word, and let not discontent

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Daunt all your hopes: madam, he comforts you

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Can make you greater than the Queen of Goths.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Lavinia, you are not displeased with this?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Not I, my lord; sith true nobility

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Warrants these words in princely courtesy.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thanks, sweet Lavinia. Romans, let us go;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Ransomless here we set our prisoners free:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Proclaim our honours, lords, with trump and drum.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Flourish. SATURNINUS courts TAMORA in dumb show

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Lord Titus, by your leave, this maid is mine.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Seizing LAVINIA

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: How, sir! are you in earnest then, my lord?

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Ay, noble Titus; and resolved withal

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: To do myself this reason and this right.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Suum cuique' is our Roman justice:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This prince in justice seizeth but his own.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And that he will, and shall, if Lucius live.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Traitors, avaunt! Where is the emperor's guard?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Treason, my lord! Lavinia is surprised!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Surprised! by whom?

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: By him that justly may

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Bear his betroth'd from all the world away.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Exeunt BASSIANUS and MARCUS with LAVINIA

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: Brothers, help to convey her hence away,

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: And with my sword I'll keep this door safe.

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: Exeunt LUCIUS, QUINTUS, and MARTIUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Follow, my lord, and I'll soon bring her back.

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: My lord, you pass not here.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What, villain boy!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Barr'st me my way in Rome?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Stabbing MUTIUS

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: Help, Lucius, help!

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: Dies

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: During the fray, SATURNINUS, TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON and AARON go out and re-enter, above

speaker: MUTIUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My lord, you are unjust, and, more than so,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: In wrongful quarrel you have slain your son.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Nor thou, nor he, are any sons of mine;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My sons would never so dishonour me:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Traitor, restore Lavinia to the emperor.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Dead, if you will; but not to be his wife,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That is another's lawful promised love.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: No, Titus, no; the emperor needs her not,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Nor her, nor thee, nor any of thy stock:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I'll trust, by leisure, him that mocks me once;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thee never, nor thy traitorous haughty sons,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Confederates all thus to dishonour me.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Was there none else in Rome to make a stale,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But Saturnine? Full well, Andronicus,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Agree these deeds with that proud brag of thine,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That said'st I begg'd the empire at thy hands.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O monstrous! what reproachful words are these?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But go thy ways; go, give that changing piece

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: To him that flourish'd for her with his sword

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: A valiant son-in-law thou shalt enjoy;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: One fit to bandy with thy lawless sons,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: To ruffle in the commonwealth of Rome.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These words are razors to my wounded heart.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And therefore, lovely Tamora, queen of Goths,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That like the stately Phoebe 'mongst her nymphs

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Dost overshine the gallant'st dames of Rome,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: If thou be pleased with this my sudden choice,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Behold, I choose thee, Tamora, for my bride,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And will create thee empress of Rome,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Speak, Queen of Goths, dost thou applaud my choice?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And here I swear by all the Roman gods,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sith priest and holy water are so near

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And tapers burn so bright and every thing

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: In readiness for Hymenaeus stand,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I will not re-salute the streets of Rome,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Or climb my palace, till from forth this place

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I lead espoused my bride along with me.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And here, in sight of heaven, to Rome I swear,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: If Saturnine advance the Queen of Goths,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: She will a handmaid be to his desires,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: A loving nurse, a mother to his youth.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Ascend, fair queen, Pantheon. Lords, accompany

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Your noble emperor and his lovely bride,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sent by the heavens for Prince Saturnine,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Whose wisdom hath her fortune conquered:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: There shall we consummate our spousal rites.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but TITUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I am not bid to wait upon this bride.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Titus, when wert thou wont to walk alone,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Dishonour'd thus, and challenged of wrongs?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Re-enter MARCUS, LUCIUS, QUINTUS, and MARTIUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O Titus, see, O, see what thou hast done!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: In a bad quarrel slain a virtuous son.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No, foolish tribune, no; no son of mine,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Nor thou, nor these, confederates in the deed

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That hath dishonour'd all our family;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Unworthy brother, and unworthy sons!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But let us give him burial, as becomes;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Give Mutius burial with our brethren.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Traitors, away! he rests not in this tomb:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This monument five hundred years hath stood,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Which I have sumptuously re-edified:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here none but soldiers and Rome's servitors

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Repose in fame; none basely slain in brawls:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Bury him where you can; he comes not here.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My lord, this is impiety in you:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My nephew Mutius' deeds do plead for him

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: He must be buried with his brethren.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: And shall, or him we will accompany.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'And shall!' what villain was it that spake

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: that word?

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: He that would vouch it in any place but here.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What, would you bury him in my despite?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No, noble Titus, but entreat of thee

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To pardon Mutius and to bury him.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Marcus, even thou hast struck upon my crest,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, with these boys, mine honour thou hast wounded:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My foes I do repute you every one;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: So, trouble me no more, but get you gone.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: He is not with himself; let us withdraw.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Not I, till Mutius' bones be buried.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: MARCUS and the Sons of TITUS kneel

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Brother, for in that name doth nature plead,--

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Father, and in that name doth nature speak,--

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Speak thou no more, if all the rest will speed.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Renowned Titus, more than half my soul,--

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Dear father, soul and substance of us all,--

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Suffer thy brother Marcus to inter

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: His noble nephew here in virtue's nest,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That died in honour and Lavinia's cause.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thou art a Roman; be not barbarous:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The Greeks upon advice did bury Ajax

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That slew himself; and wise Laertes' son

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Did graciously plead for his funerals:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Let not young Mutius, then, that was thy joy

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Be barr'd his entrance here.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rise, Marcus, rise.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The dismall'st day is this that e'er I saw,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To be dishonour'd by my sons in Rome!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Well, bury him, and bury me the next.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: MUTIUS is put into the tomb

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: There lie thy bones, sweet Mutius, with thy friends,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Till we with trophies do adorn thy tomb.

speaker: All
text_entry: [Kneeling]  No man shed tears for noble Mutius;

speaker: All
text_entry: He lives in fame that died in virtue's cause.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My lord, to step out of these dreary dumps,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: How comes it that the subtle Queen of Goths

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is of a sudden thus advanced in Rome?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I know not, Marcus; but I know it is,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whether by device or no, the heavens can tell:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is she not then beholding to the man

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That brought her for this high good turn so far?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Yes, and will nobly him remunerate.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Flourish. Re-enter, from one side, SATURNINUS  attended, TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON and AARON; from the other, BASSIANUS, LAVINIA, and others

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: So, Bassianus, you have play'd your prize:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: God give you joy, sir, of your gallant bride!

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And you of yours, my lord! I say no more,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Nor wish no less; and so, I take my leave.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Traitor, if Rome have law or we have power,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thou and thy faction shall repent this rape.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Rape, call you it, my lord, to seize my own,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: My truth-betrothed love and now my wife?

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: But let the laws of Rome determine all;

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Meanwhile I am possess'd of that is mine.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: 'Tis good, sir: you are very short with us;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But, if we live, we'll be as sharp with you.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: My lord, what I have done, as best I may,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Answer I must and shall do with my life.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Only thus much I give your grace to know:

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: By all the duties that I owe to Rome,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: This noble gentleman, Lord Titus here,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Is in opinion and in honour wrong'd;

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: That in the rescue of Lavinia

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: With his own hand did slay his youngest son,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: In zeal to you and highly moved to wrath

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: To be controll'd in that he frankly gave:

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Receive him, then, to favor, Saturnine,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: That hath express'd himself in all his deeds

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: A father and a friend to thee and Rome.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Prince Bassianus, leave to plead my deeds:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Tis thou and those that have dishonour'd me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rome and the righteous heavens be my judge,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: How I have loved and honour'd Saturnine!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: My worthy lord, if ever Tamora

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Were gracious in those princely eyes of thine,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then hear me speak in indifferently for all;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And at my suit, sweet, pardon what is past.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What, madam! be dishonour'd openly,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And basely put it up without revenge?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Not so, my lord; the gods of Rome forfend

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I should be author to dishonour you!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But on mine honour dare I undertake

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For good Lord Titus' innocence in all;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Whose fury not dissembled speaks his griefs:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then, at my suit, look graciously on him;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Lose not so noble a friend on vain suppose,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Nor with sour looks afflict his gentle heart.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Aside to SATURNINUS

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: be won at last;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Dissemble all your griefs and discontents:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: You are but newly planted in your throne;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Lest, then, the people, and patricians too,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Upon a just survey, take Titus' part,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And so supplant you for ingratitude,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Which Rome reputes to be a heinous sin,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Yield at entreats; and then let me alone:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I'll find a day to massacre them all

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And raze their faction and their family,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The cruel father and his traitorous sons,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To whom I sued for my dear son's life,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And make them know what 'tis to let a queen

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Kneel in the streets and beg for grace in vain.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Aloud

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Come, come, sweet emperor; come, Andronicus;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Take up this good old man, and cheer the heart

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: That dies in tempest of thy angry frown.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Rise, Titus, rise; my empress hath prevail'd.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I thank your majesty, and her, my lord:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These words, these looks, infuse new life in me.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Titus, I am incorporate in Rome,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: A Roman now adopted happily,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And must advise the emperor for his good.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: This day all quarrels die, Andronicus;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And let it be mine honour, good my lord,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: That I have reconciled your friends and you.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For you, Prince Bassianus, I have pass'd

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: My word and promise to the emperor,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: That you will be more mild and tractable.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And fear not lords, and you, Lavinia;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: By my advice, all humbled on your knees,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: You shall ask pardon of his majesty.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: We do, and vow to heaven and to his highness,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That what we did was mildly as we might,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Tendering our sister's honour and our own.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That, on mine honour, here I do protest.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Away, and talk not; trouble us no more.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Nay, nay, sweet emperor, we must all be friends:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The tribune and his nephews kneel for grace;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I will not be denied: sweet heart, look back.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Marcus, for thy sake and thy brother's here,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And at my lovely Tamora's entreats,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I do remit these young men's heinous faults: Stand up.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Lavinia, though you left me like a churl,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I found a friend, and sure as death I swore

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I would not part a bachelor from the priest.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Come, if the emperor's court can feast two brides,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: You are my guest, Lavinia, and your friends.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: This day shall be a love-day, Tamora.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To-morrow, an it please your majesty

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To hunt the panther and the hart with me,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: With horn and hound we'll give your grace bonjour.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Be it so, Titus, and gramercy too.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. Before the Palace.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Enter AARON

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Now climbeth Tamora Olympus' top,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Safe out of fortune's shot; and sits aloft,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Secure of thunder's crack or lightning flash;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Advanced above pale envy's threatening reach.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As when the golden sun salutes the morn,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And, having gilt the ocean with his beams,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Gallops the zodiac in his glistering coach,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And overlooks the highest-peering hills;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: So Tamora:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Upon her wit doth earthly honour wait,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And virtue stoops and trembles at her frown.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Then, Aaron, arm thy heart, and fit thy thoughts,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To mount aloft with thy imperial mistress,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And mount her pitch, whom thou in triumph long

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Hast prisoner held, fetter'd in amorous chains

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And faster bound to Aaron's charming eyes

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Than is Prometheus tied to Caucasus.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Away with slavish weeds and servile thoughts!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I will be bright, and shine in pearl and gold,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To wait upon this new-made empress.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To wait, said I? to wanton with this queen,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This goddess, this Semiramis, this nymph,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This siren, that will charm Rome's Saturnine,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And see his shipwreck and his commonweal's.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Holloa! what storm is this?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, braving

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Chiron, thy years want wit, thy wit wants edge,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And manners, to intrude where I am graced;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And may, for aught thou know'st, affected be.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Demetrius, thou dost over-ween in all;

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And so in this, to bear me down with braves.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: 'Tis not the difference of a year or two

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Makes me less gracious or thee more fortunate:

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: I am as able and as fit as thou

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: To serve, and to deserve my mistress' grace;

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And that my sword upon thee shall approve,

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And plead my passions for Lavinia's love.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: [Aside]  Clubs, clubs! these lovers will not keep

speaker: AARON
text_entry: the peace.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Why, boy, although our mother, unadvised,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Gave you a dancing-rapier by your side,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Are you so desperate grown, to threat your friends?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Go to; have your lath glued within your sheath

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Till you know better how to handle it.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Meanwhile, sir, with the little skill I have,

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Full well shalt thou perceive how much I dare.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Ay, boy, grow ye so brave?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: They draw

speaker: AARON
text_entry: [Coming forward]  Why, how now, lords!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: So near the emperor's palace dare you draw,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And maintain such a quarrel openly?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Full well I wot the ground of all this grudge:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I would not for a million of gold

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The cause were known to them it most concerns;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Nor would your noble mother for much more

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Be so dishonour'd in the court of Rome.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: For shame, put up.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Not I, till I have sheathed

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: My rapier in his bosom and withal

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Thrust these reproachful speeches down his throat

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: That he hath breathed in my dishonour here.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: For that I am prepared and full resolved.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Foul-spoken coward, that thunder'st with thy tongue,

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And with thy weapon nothing darest perform!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Away, I say!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Now, by the gods that warlike Goths adore,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This petty brabble will undo us all.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Why, lords, and think you not how dangerous

speaker: AARON
text_entry: It is to jet upon a prince's right?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: What, is Lavinia then become so loose,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Or Bassianus so degenerate,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That for her love such quarrels may be broach'd

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Without controlment, justice, or revenge?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Young lords, beware! and should the empress know

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This discord's ground, the music would not please.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: I care not, I, knew she and all the world:

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: I love Lavinia more than all the world.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Youngling, learn thou to make some meaner choice:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Lavinia is thine elder brother's hope.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Why, are ye mad? or know ye not, in Rome

speaker: AARON
text_entry: How furious and impatient they be,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And cannot brook competitors in love?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I tell you, lords, you do but plot your deaths

speaker: AARON
text_entry: By this device.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Aaron, a thousand deaths

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Would I propose to achieve her whom I love.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To achieve her! how?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Why makest thou it so strange?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: She is a woman, therefore may be woo'd;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: She is a woman, therefore may be won;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: She is Lavinia, therefore must be loved.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: What, man! more water glideth by the mill

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Than wots the miller of; and easy it is

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Of a cut loaf to steal a shive, we know:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Though Bassianus be the emperor's brother.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Better than he have worn Vulcan's badge.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: [Aside]  Ay, and as good as Saturninus may.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Then why should he despair that knows to court it

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: With words, fair looks and liberality?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: What, hast not thou full often struck a doe,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And borne her cleanly by the keeper's nose?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Why, then, it seems, some certain snatch or so

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Would serve your turns.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Ay, so the turn were served.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Aaron, thou hast hit it.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Would you had hit it too!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Then should not we be tired with this ado.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Why, hark ye, hark ye! and are you such fools

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To square for this? would it offend you, then

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That both should speed?

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Faith, not me.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Nor me, so I were one.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: For shame, be friends, and join for that you jar:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: 'Tis policy and stratagem must do

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That you affect; and so must you resolve,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That what you cannot as you would achieve,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: You must perforce accomplish as you may.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Take this of me: Lucrece was not more chaste

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Than this Lavinia, Bassianus' love.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: A speedier course than lingering languishment

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Must we pursue, and I have found the path.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: My lords, a solemn hunting is in hand;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: There will the lovely Roman ladies troop:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The forest walks are wide and spacious;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And many unfrequented plots there are

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Fitted by kind for rape and villany:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Single you thither then this dainty doe,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And strike her home by force, if not by words:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This way, or not at all, stand you in hope.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Come, come, our empress, with her sacred wit

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To villany and vengeance consecrate,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Will we acquaint with all that we intend;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And she shall file our engines with advice,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That will not suffer you to square yourselves,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: But to your wishes' height advance you both.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The emperor's court is like the house of Fame,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The palace full of tongues, of eyes, and ears:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The woods are ruthless, dreadful, deaf, and dull;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: There speak, and strike, brave boys, and take

speaker: AARON
text_entry: your turns;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: There serve your lusts, shadow'd from heaven's eye,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And revel in Lavinia's treasury.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Thy counsel, lad, smells of no cowardice,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Sit fas aut nefas, till I find the stream

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To cool this heat, a charm to calm these fits.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Per Styga, per manes vehor.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. A forest near Rome. Horns and cry of hounds heard.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter TITUS ANDRONICUS, with Hunters,  and c., MARCUS, LUCIUS, QUINTUS, and MARTIUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The hunt is up, the morn is bright and grey,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The fields are fragrant and the woods are green:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Uncouple here and let us make a bay

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And wake the emperor and his lovely bride

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And rouse the prince and ring a hunter's peal,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That all the court may echo with the noise.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sons, let it be your charge, as it is ours,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To attend the emperor's person carefully:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I have been troubled in my sleep this night,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But dawning day new comfort hath inspired.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A cry of hounds and horns, winded in a peal. Enter  SATURNINUS, TAMORA, BASSIANUS, LAVINIA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, and Attendants

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Many good morrows to your majesty;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Madam, to you as many and as good:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I promised your grace a hunter's peal.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And you have rung it lustily, my lord;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Somewhat too early for new-married ladies.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Lavinia, how say you?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: I say, no;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: I have been broad awake two hours and more.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Come on, then; horse and chariots let us have,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And to our sport.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: To TAMORA

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Madam, now shall ye see

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Our Roman hunting.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I have dogs, my lord,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will rouse the proudest panther in the chase,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And climb the highest promontory top.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And I have horse will follow where the game

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Makes way, and run like swallows o'er the plain.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Chiron, we hunt not, we, with horse nor hound,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: But hope to pluck a dainty doe to ground.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: SCENE III. A lonely part of the forest.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter AARON, with a bag of gold

speaker: AARON
text_entry: He that had wit would think that I had none,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To bury so much gold under a tree,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And never after to inherit it.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Let him that thinks of me so abjectly

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Know that this gold must coin a stratagem,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which, cunningly effected, will beget

speaker: AARON
text_entry: A very excellent piece of villany:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And so repose, sweet gold, for their unrest

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Hides the gold

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That have their alms out of the empress' chest.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Enter TAMORA

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: My lovely Aaron, wherefore look'st thou sad,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: When every thing doth make a gleeful boast?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The birds chant melody on every bush,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The snake lies rolled in the cheerful sun,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And make a chequer'd shadow on the ground:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Under their sweet shade, Aaron, let us sit,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, whilst the babbling echo mocks the hounds,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Replying shrilly to the well-tuned horns,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: As if a double hunt were heard at once,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Let us sit down and mark their yelping noise;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, after conflict such as was supposed

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The wandering prince and Dido once enjoy'd,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: When with a happy storm they were surprised

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And curtain'd with a counsel-keeping cave,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: We may, each wreathed in the other's arms,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Our pastimes done, possess a golden slumber;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Whiles hounds and horns and sweet melodious birds

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Be unto us as is a nurse's song

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Of lullaby to bring her babe asleep.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Madam, though Venus govern your desires,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Saturn is dominator over mine:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: What signifies my deadly-standing eye,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: My silence and my cloudy melancholy,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: My fleece of woolly hair that now uncurls

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Even as an adder when she doth unroll

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To do some fatal execution?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: No, madam, these are no venereal signs:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Blood and revenge are hammering in my head.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Hark Tamora, the empress of my soul,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which never hopes more heaven than rests in thee,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This is the day of doom for Bassianus:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: His Philomel must lose her tongue to-day,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Thy sons make pillage of her chastity

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And wash their hands in Bassianus' blood.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Seest thou this letter? take it up, I pray thee,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And give the king this fatal plotted scroll.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Now question me no more; we are espied;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Here comes a parcel of our hopeful booty,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which dreads not yet their lives' destruction.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Ah, my sweet Moor, sweeter to me than life!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: No more, great empress; Bassianus comes:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Be cross with him; and I'll go fetch thy sons

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To back thy quarrels, whatsoe'er they be.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Enter BASSIANUS and LAVINIA

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Who have we here? Rome's royal empress,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Unfurnish'd of her well-beseeming troop?

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Or is it Dian, habited like her,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Who hath abandoned her holy groves

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: To see the general hunting in this forest?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Saucy controller of our private steps!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Had I the power that some say Dian had,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Thy temples should be planted presently

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: With horns, as was Actaeon's; and the hounds

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Should drive upon thy new-transformed limbs,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Unmannerly intruder as thou art!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Under your patience, gentle empress,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis thought you have a goodly gift in horning;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And to be doubted that your Moor and you

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Are singled forth to try experiments:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Jove shield your husband from his hounds to-day!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis pity they should take him for a stag.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Believe me, queen, your swarth Cimmerian

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Doth make your honour of his body's hue,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Spotted, detested, and abominable.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Why are you sequester'd from all your train,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Dismounted from your snow-white goodly steed.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: And wander'd hither to an obscure plot,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: Accompanied but with a barbarous Moor,

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: If foul desire had not conducted you?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And, being intercepted in your sport,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Great reason that my noble lord be rated

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: For sauciness. I pray you, let us hence,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And let her joy her raven-colour'd love;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: This valley fits the purpose passing well.

speaker: BASSIANUS
text_entry: The king my brother shall have note of this.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Ay, for these slips have made him noted long:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Good king, to be so mightily abused!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why have I patience to endure all this?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: How now, dear sovereign, and our gracious mother!

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Why doth your highness look so pale and wan?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Have I not reason, think you, to look pale?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: These two have 'ticed me hither to this place:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: A barren detested vale, you see it is;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The trees, though summer, yet forlorn and lean,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: O'ercome with moss and baleful mistletoe:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Here never shines the sun; here nothing breeds,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Unless the nightly owl or fatal raven:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And when they show'd me this abhorred pit,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: They told me, here, at dead time of the night,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: A thousand fiends, a thousand hissing snakes,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Ten thousand swelling toads, as many urchins,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Would make such fearful and confused cries

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: As any mortal body hearing it

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Should straight fall mad, or else die suddenly.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: No sooner had they told this hellish tale,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But straight they told me they would bind me here

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Unto the body of a dismal yew,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And leave me to this miserable death:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And then they call'd me foul adulteress,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Lascivious Goth, and all the bitterest terms

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: That ever ear did hear to such effect:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, had you not by wondrous fortune come,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: This vengeance on me had they executed.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Revenge it, as you love your mother's life,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Or be ye not henceforth call'd my children.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: This is a witness that I am thy son.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Stabs BASSIANUS

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And this for me, struck home to show my strength.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Also stabs BASSIANUS, who dies

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Ay, come, Semiramis, nay, barbarous Tamora,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: For no name fits thy nature but thy own!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Give me thy poniard; you shall know, my boys

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Stay, madam; here is more belongs to her;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: First thrash the corn, then after burn the straw:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: This minion stood upon her chastity,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Upon her nuptial vow, her loyalty,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And with that painted hope braves your mightiness:

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And shall she carry this unto her grave?

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: An if she do, I would I were an eunuch.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Drag hence her husband to some secret hole,

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And make his dead trunk pillow to our lust.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But when ye have the honey ye desire,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Let not this wasp outlive, us both to sting.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: I warrant you, madam, we wil l make that sure.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Come, mistress, now perforce we will enjoy

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: That nice-preserved honesty of yours.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O Tamora! thou bear'st a woman's face,--

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I will not hear her speak; away with her!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Sweet lords, entreat her hear me but a word.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Listen, fair madam: let it be your glory

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: To see her tears; but be your heart to them

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: As unrelenting flint to drops of rain.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: When did the tiger's young ones teach the dam?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, do not learn her wrath; she taught it thee;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The milk thou suck'dst from her did turn to marble;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Even at thy teat thou hadst thy tyranny.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Yet every mother breeds not sons alike:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: To CHIRON

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Do thou entreat her show a woman pity.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: What, wouldst thou have me prove myself a bastard?

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis true; the raven doth not hatch a lark:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Yet have I heard,--O, could I find it now!--

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The lion moved with pity did endure

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: To have his princely paws pared all away:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Some say that ravens foster forlorn children,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The whilst their own birds famish in their nests:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, be to me, though thy hard heart say no,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Nothing so kind, but something pitiful!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I know not what it means; away with her!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, let me teach thee! for my father's sake,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: That gave thee life, when well he might have

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: slain thee,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Be not obdurate, open thy deaf ears.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Hadst thou in person ne'er offended me,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Even for his sake am I pitiless.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Remember, boys, I pour'd forth tears in vain,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To save your brother from the sacrifice;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But fierce Andronicus would not relent;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Therefore, away with her, and use her as you will,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The worse to her, the better loved of me.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O Tamora, be call'd a gentle queen,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And with thine own hands kill me in this place!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: For 'tis not life that I have begg'd so long;

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Poor I was slain when Bassianus died.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: What begg'st thou, then? fond woman, let me go.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: 'Tis present death I beg; and one thing more

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: That womanhood denies my tongue to tell:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: O, keep me from their worse than killing lust,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: And tumble me into some loathsome pit,

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Where never man's eye may behold my body:

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Do this, and be a charitable murderer.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: So should I rob my sweet sons of their fee:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: No, let them satisfy their lust on thee.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Away! for thou hast stay'd us here too long.

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: No grace? no womanhood? Ah, beastly creature!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: The blot and enemy to our general name!

speaker: LAVINIA
text_entry: Confusion fall--

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Nay, then I'll stop your mouth. Bring thou her husband:

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: This is the hole where Aaron bid us hide him.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: DEMETRIUS throws the body of BASSIANUS into the  pit; then exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, dragging off LAVINIA

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Farewell, my sons: see that you make her sure.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Ne'er let my heart know merry cheer indeed,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Till all the Andronici be made away.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Now will I hence to seek my lovely Moor,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And let my spleenful sons this trull deflow'r.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Re-enter AARON, with QUINTUS and MARTIUS

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Come on, my lords, the better foot before:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Straight will I bring you to the loathsome pit

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Where I espied the panther fast asleep.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: My sight is very dull, whate'er it bodes.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: And mine, I promise you; were't not for shame,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Well could I leave our sport to sleep awhile.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Falls into the pit

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: What art thou fall'n? What subtle hole is this,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Whose mouth is cover'd with rude-growing briers,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Upon whose leaves are drops of new-shed blood

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: As fresh as morning dew distill'd on flowers?

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: A very fatal place it seems to me.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Speak, brother, hast thou hurt thee with the fall?

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: O brother, with the dismall'st object hurt

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: That ever eye with sight made heart lament!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: [Aside]  Now will I fetch the king to find them here,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That he thereby may give a likely guess

speaker: AARON
text_entry: How these were they that made away his brother.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Why dost not comfort me, and help me out

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: From this unhallowed and blood-stained hole?

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: I am surprised with an uncouth fear;

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: A chilling sweat o'er-runs my trembling joints:

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: My heart suspects more than mine eye can see.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: To prove thou hast a true-divining heart,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Aaron and thou look down into this den,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: And see a fearful sight of blood and death.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Aaron is gone; and my compassionate heart

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Will not permit mine eyes once to behold

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: The thing whereat it trembles by surmise;

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: O, tell me how it is; for ne'er till now

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Was I a child to fear I know not what.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Lord Bassianus lies embrewed here,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: All on a heap, like to a slaughter'd lamb,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: In this detested, dark, blood-drinking pit.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: If it be dark, how dost thou know 'tis he?

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Upon his bloody finger he doth wear

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: A precious ring, that lightens all the hole,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Which, like a taper in some monument,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Doth shine upon the dead man's earthy cheeks,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: And shows the ragged entrails of the pit:

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: So pale did shine the moon on Pyramus

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: When he by night lay bathed in maiden blood.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: O brother, help me with thy fainting hand--

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: If fear hath made thee faint, as me it hath--

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Out of this fell devouring receptacle,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: As hateful as Cocytus' misty mouth.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Reach me thy hand, that I may help thee out;

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Or, wanting strength to do thee so much good,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: I may be pluck'd into the swallowing womb

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Of this deep pit, poor Bassianus' grave.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: I have no strength to pluck thee to the brink.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Nor I no strength to climb without thy help.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Thy hand once more; I will not loose again,

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Till thou art here aloft, or I below:

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Thou canst not come to me: I come to thee.

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Falls in

speaker: QUINTUS
text_entry: Enter SATURNINUS with AARON

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Along with me: I'll see what hole is here,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And what he is that now is leap'd into it.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Say who art thou that lately didst descend

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Into this gaping hollow of the earth?

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: The unhappy son of old Andronicus:

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Brought hither in a most unlucky hour,

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: To find thy brother Bassianus dead.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: My brother dead! I know thou dost but jest:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: He and his lady both are at the lodge

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Upon the north side of this pleasant chase;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: 'Tis not an hour since I left him there.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: We know not where you left him all alive;

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: But, out, alas! here have we found him dead.

speaker: MARTIUS
text_entry: Re-enter TAMORA, with Attendants; TITUS ANDRONICUS, and Lucius

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Where is my lord the king?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Here, Tamora, though grieved with killing grief.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Where is thy brother Bassianus?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Now to the bottom dost thou search my wound:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Poor Bassianus here lies murdered.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then all too late I bring this fatal writ,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The complot of this timeless tragedy;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And wonder greatly that man's face can fold

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: In pleasing smiles such murderous tyranny.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: She giveth SATURNINUS a letter

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: [Reads]  'An if we miss to meet him handsomely--

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sweet huntsman, Bassianus 'tis we mean--

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Do thou so much as dig the grave for him:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thou know'st our meaning. Look for thy reward

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Among the nettles at the elder-tree

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Which overshades the mouth of that same pit

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Where we decreed to bury Bassianus.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Do this, and purchase us thy lasting friends.'

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: O Tamora! was ever heard the like?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: This is the pit, and this the elder-tree.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Look, sirs, if you can find the huntsman out

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That should have murdered Bassianus here.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: My gracious lord, here is the bag of gold.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: [To TITUS]  Two of thy whelps, fell curs of

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: bloody kind,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Have here bereft my brother of his life.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sirs, drag them from the pit unto the prison:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: There let them bide until we have devised

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Some never-heard-of torturing pain for them.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: What, are they in this pit? O wondrous thing!

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: How easily murder is discovered!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: High emperor, upon my feeble knee

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I beg this boon, with tears not lightly shed,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That this fell fault of my accursed sons,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Accursed if the fault be proved in them,--

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: If it be proved! you see it is apparent.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Who found this letter? Tamora, was it you?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Andronicus himself did take it up.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I did, my lord: yet let me be their bail;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For, by my father's reverend tomb, I vow

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They shall be ready at your highness' will

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To answer their suspicion with their lives.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Thou shalt not bail them: see thou follow me.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Some bring the murder'd body, some the murderers:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Let them not speak a word; the guilt is plain;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: For, by my soul, were there worse end than death,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That end upon them should be executed.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Andronicus, I will entreat the king;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Fear not thy sons; they shall do well enough.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, Lucius, come; stay not to talk with them.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. Another part of the forest.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter DEMETRIUS and CHIRON with LAVINIA, ravished; her hands cut off, and her tongue cut out

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: So, now go tell, an if thy tongue can speak,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Who 'twas that cut thy tongue and ravish'd thee.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Write down thy mind, bewray thy meaning so,

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: An if thy stumps will let thee play the scribe.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: See, how with signs and tokens she can scrowl.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Go home, call for sweet water, wash thy hands.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: She hath no tongue to call, nor hands to wash;

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: And so let's leave her to her silent walks.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: An 'twere my case, I should go hang myself.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: If thou hadst hands to help thee knit the cord.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Enter MARCUS

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Who is this? my niece, that flies away so fast!

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Cousin, a word; where is your husband?

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: If I do dream, would all my wealth would wake me!

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: If I do wake, some planet strike me down,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: That I may slumber in eternal sleep!

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Speak, gentle niece, what stern ungentle hands

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Have lopp'd and hew'd and made thy body bare

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Of her two branches, those sweet ornaments,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Whose circling shadows kings have sought to sleep in,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: And might not gain so great a happiness

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: As have thy love? Why dost not speak to me?

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Alas, a crimson river of warm blood,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Like to a bubbling fountain stirr'd with wind,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Doth rise and fall between thy rosed lips,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Coming and going with thy honey breath.

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: But, sure, some Tereus hath deflowered thee,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: And, lest thou shouldst detect him, cut thy tongue.

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Ah, now thou turn'st away thy face for shame!

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: And, notwithstanding all this loss of blood,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: As from a conduit with three issuing spouts,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Yet do thy cheeks look red as Titan's face

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Blushing to be encountered with a cloud.

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: Shall I speak for thee? shall I say 'tis so?

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: O, that I knew thy heart; and knew the beast,

speaker: MARCUS
text_entry: That I might rail at him, to ease my mind!

speaker: MARCUS
