text_entry: And substituted in the place of mine,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To calm this tempest whirling in the court;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And let the emperor dandle him for his own.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Hark ye, lords; ye see I have given her physic,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Pointing to the nurse

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And you must needs bestow her funeral;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The fields are near, and you are gallant grooms:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: This done, see that you take no longer days,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: But send the midwife presently to me.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The midwife and the nurse well made away,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Then let the ladies tattle what they please.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Aaron, I see thou wilt not trust the air

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: With secrets.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: For this care of Tamora,

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Herself and hers are highly bound to thee.

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON bearing off the Nurse's body

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Now to the Goths, as swift as swallow flies;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: There to dispose this treasure in mine arms,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And secretly to greet the empress' friends.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Come on, you thick lipp'd slave, I'll bear you hence;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: For it is you that puts us to our shifts:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I'll make you feed on berries and on roots,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And feed on curds and whey, and suck the goat,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And cabin in a cave, and bring you up

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To be a warrior, and command a camp.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Exit

speaker: AARON
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. A public place.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Enter TITUS, bearing arrows with letters at the  ends of them; with him, MARCUS, Young LUCIUS,  PUBLIUS, SEMPRONIUS, CAIUS, and other Gentlemen, with bows

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, Marcus; come, kinsmen; this is the way.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sir boy, now let me see your archery;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Look ye draw home enough, and 'tis there straight.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Terras Astraea reliquit:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Be you remember'd, Marcus, she's gone, she's fled.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sirs, take you to your tools. You, cousins, shall

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Go sound the ocean, and cast your nets;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Happily you may catch her in the sea;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Yet there's as little justice as at land:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No; Publius and Sempronius, you must do it;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Tis you must dig with mattock and with spade,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And pierce the inmost centre of the earth:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then, when you come to Pluto's region,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I pray you, deliver him this petition;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tell him, it is for justice and for aid,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And that it comes from old Andronicus,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Shaken with sorrows in ungrateful Rome.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ah, Rome! Well, well; I made thee miserable

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What time I threw the people's suffrages

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: On him that thus doth tyrannize o'er me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Go, get you gone; and pray be careful all,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And leave you not a man-of-war unsearch'd:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This wicked emperor may have shipp'd her hence;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, kinsmen, then we may go pipe for justice.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O Publius, is not this a heavy case,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To see thy noble uncle thus distract?

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Therefore, my lord, it highly us concerns

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: By day and night to attend him carefully,

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: And feed his humour kindly as we may,

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Till time beget some careful remedy.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kinsmen, his sorrows are past remedy.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Join with the Goths; and with revengeful war

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Take wreak on Rome for this ingratitude,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And vengeance on the traitor Saturnine.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Publius, how now! how now, my masters!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What, have you met with her?

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: No, my good lord; but Pluto sends you word,

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: If you will have Revenge from hell, you shall:

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Marry, for Justice, she is so employ'd,

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: He thinks, with Jove in heaven, or somewhere else,

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: So that perforce you must needs stay a time.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: He doth me wrong to feed me with delays.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I'll dive into the burning lake below,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And pull her out of Acheron by the heels.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Marcus, we are but shrubs, no cedars we

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No big-boned men framed of the Cyclops' size;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But metal, Marcus, steel to the very back,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Yet wrung with wrongs more than our backs can bear:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, sith there's no justice in earth nor hell,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: We will solicit heaven and move the gods

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To send down Justice for to wreak our wrongs.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, to this gear. You are a good archer, Marcus;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: He gives them the arrows

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Ad Jovem,' that's for you: here, 'Ad Apollinem:'

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Ad Martem,' that's for myself:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here, boy, to Pallas: here, to Mercury:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To Saturn, Caius, not to Saturnine;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You were as good to shoot against the wind.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To it, boy! Marcus, loose when I bid.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Of my word, I have written to effect;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: There's not a god left unsolicited.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kinsmen, shoot all your shafts into the court:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: We will afflict the emperor in his pride.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now, masters, draw.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They shoot

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, well said, Lucius!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Good boy, in Virgo's lap; give it Pallas.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My lord, I aim a mile beyond the moon;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Your letter is with Jupiter by this.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Ha, ha!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Publius, Publius, what hast thou done?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: See, see, thou hast shot off one of Taurus' horns.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This was the sport, my lord: when Publius shot,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The Bull, being gall'd, gave Aries such a knock

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That down fell both the Ram's horns in the court;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And who should find them but the empress' villain?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: She laugh'd, and told the Moor he should not choose

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But give them to his master for a present.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, there it goes: God give his lordship joy!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter a Clown, with a basket, and two pigeons in it

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: News, news from heaven! Marcus, the post is come.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sirrah, what tidings? have you any letters?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Shall I have justice? what says Jupiter?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: O, the gibbet-maker! he says that he hath taken

speaker: Clown
text_entry: them down again, for the man must not be hanged till

speaker: Clown
text_entry: the next week.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But what says Jupiter, I ask thee?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Alas, sir, I know not Jupiter; I never drank with him

speaker: Clown
text_entry: in all my life.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, villain, art not thou the carrier?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Ay, of my pigeons, sir; nothing else.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, didst thou not come from heaven?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: From heaven! alas, sir, I never came there     God

speaker: Clown
text_entry: forbid I should be so bold to press to heaven in my

speaker: Clown
text_entry: young days. Why, I am going with my pigeons to the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: tribunal plebs, to take up a matter of brawl

speaker: Clown
text_entry: betwixt my uncle and one of the emperial's men.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, sir, that is as fit as can be to serve for

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: your oration; and let him deliver the pigeons to

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: the emperor from you.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tell me, can you deliver an oration to the emperor

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: with a grace?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Nay, truly, sir, I could never say grace in all my life.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sirrah, come hither: make no more ado,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But give your pigeons to the emperor:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: By me thou shalt have justice at his hands.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hold, hold; meanwhile here's money for thy charges.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Give me pen and ink. Sirrah, can you with a grace

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: deliver a supplication?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Ay, sir.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Then here is a supplication for you. And when you

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: come to him, at the first approach you must kneel,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: then kiss his foot, then deliver up your pigeons, and

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: then look for your reward. I'll be at hand, sir; see

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: you do it bravely.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I warrant you, sir, let me alone.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sirrah, hast thou a knife? come, let me see it.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here, Marcus, fold it in the oration;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For thou hast made it like an humble suppliant.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And when thou hast given it the emperor,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Knock at my door, and tell me what he says.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: God be with you, sir; I will.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, Marcus, let us go. Publius, follow me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. The same. Before the palace.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter SATURNINUS, TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON,  Lords, and others; SATURNINUS with the arrows in his hand that TITUS shot

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Why, lords, what wrongs are these! was ever seen

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: An emperor in Rome thus overborne,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Troubled, confronted thus; and, for the extent

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Of egal justice, used in such contempt?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: My lords, you know, as know the mightful gods,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: However these disturbers of our peace

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Buz in the people's ears, there nought hath pass'd,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But even with law, against the willful sons

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Of old Andronicus. And what an if

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: His sorrows have so overwhelm'd his wits,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Shall we be thus afflicted in his wreaks,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: His fits, his frenzy, and his bitterness?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And now he writes to heaven for his redress:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: See, here's to Jove, and this to Mercury;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: This to Apollo; this to the god of war;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sweet scrolls to fly about the streets of Rome!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What's this but libelling against the senate,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And blazoning our injustice every where?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: A goodly humour, is it not, my lords?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: As who would say, in Rome no justice were.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But if I live, his feigned ecstasies

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Shall be no shelter to these outrages:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But he and his shall know that justice lives

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: In Saturninus' health, whom, if she sleep,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: He'll so awake as she in fury shall

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Cut off the proud'st conspirator that lives.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: My gracious lord, my lovely Saturnine,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Lord of my life, commander of my thoughts,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Calm thee, and bear the faults of Titus' age,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The effects of sorrow for his valiant sons,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Whose loss hath pierced him deep and scarr'd his heart;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And rather comfort his distressed plight

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Than prosecute the meanest or the best

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For these contempts.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Aside

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why, thus it shall become

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: High-witted Tamora to gloze with all:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But, Titus, I have touched thee to the quick,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Thy life-blood out: if Aaron now be wise,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then is all safe, the anchor's in the port.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Enter Clown

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: How now, good fellow! wouldst thou speak with us?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Yea, forsooth, an your mistership be emperial.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Empress I am, but yonder sits the emperor.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: 'Tis he. God and Saint Stephen give you good den:

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I have brought you a letter and a couple of pigeons here.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: SATURNINUS reads the letter

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Go, take him away, and hang him presently.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: How much money must I have?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Come, sirrah, you must be hanged.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Hanged! by'r lady, then I have brought up a neck to

speaker: Clown
text_entry: a fair end.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit, guarded

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Despiteful and intolerable wrongs!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Shall I endure this monstrous villany?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: I know from whence this same device proceeds:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: May this be borne?--as if his traitorous sons,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That died by law for murder of our brother,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Have by my means been butcher'd wrongfully!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Go, drag the villain hither by the hair;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Nor age nor honour shall shape privilege:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: For this proud mock I'll be thy slaughterman;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Sly frantic wretch, that holp'st to make me great,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: In hope thyself should govern Rome and me.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Enter AEMILIUS

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What news with thee, AEmilius?

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Arm, arm, my lord;--Rome never had more cause.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: The Goths have gather'd head; and with a power

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: high-resolved men, bent to the spoil,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: They hither march amain, under conduct

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Of Lucius, son to old Andronicus;

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Who threats, in course of this revenge, to do

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: As much as ever Coriolanus did.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Is warlike Lucius general of the Goths?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: These tidings nip me, and I hang the head

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: As flowers with frost or grass beat down with storms:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Ay, now begin our sorrows to approach:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: 'Tis he the common people love so much;

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Myself hath often over-heard them say,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: When I have walked like a private man,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: That Lucius' banishment was wrongfully,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And they have wish'd that Lucius were their emperor.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why should you fear? is not your city strong?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Ay, but the citizens favor Lucius,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And will revolt from me to succor him.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: King, be thy thoughts imperious, like thy name.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Is the sun dimm'd, that gnats do fly in it?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The eagle suffers little birds to sing,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And is not careful what they mean thereby,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Knowing that with the shadow of his wings

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: He can at pleasure stint their melody:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Even so mayst thou the giddy men of Rome.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Then cheer thy spirit : for know, thou emperor,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I will enchant the old Andronicus

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: With words more sweet, and yet more dangerous,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Than baits to fish, or honey-stalks to sheep,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: When as the one is wounded with the bait,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The other rotted with delicious feed.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: But he will not entreat his son for us.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: If Tamora entreat him, then he will:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For I can smooth and fill his aged ear

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: With golden promises; that, were his heart

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Almost impregnable, his old ears deaf,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Yet should both ear and heart obey my tongue.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To AEmilius

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Go thou before, be our ambassador:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Say that the emperor requests a parley

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Of warlike Lucius, and appoint the meeting

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Even at his father's house, the old Andronicus.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: AEmilius, do this message honourably:

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And if he stand on hostage for his safety,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Bid him demand what pledge will please him best.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Your bidding shall I do effectually.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Now will I to that old Andronicus;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And temper him with all the art I have,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To pluck proud Lucius from the warlike Goths.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And now, sweet emperor, be blithe again,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And bury all thy fear in my devices.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Then go successantly, and plead to him.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Plains near Rome.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS with an army of Goths, with drum and colours

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Approved warriors, and my faithful friends,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I have received letters from great Rome,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Which signify what hate they bear their emperor

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And how desirous of our sight they are.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Therefore, great lords, be, as your titles witness,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Imperious and impatient of your wrongs,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And wherein Rome hath done you any scath,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let him make treble satisfaction.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Brave slip, sprung from the great Andronicus,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Whose name was once our terror, now our comfort;

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Whose high exploits and honourable deeds

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Ingrateful Rome requites with foul contempt,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Be bold in us: we'll follow where thou lead'st,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Like stinging bees in hottest summer's day

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: Led by their master to the flowered fields,

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: And be avenged on cursed Tamora.

speaker: All the Goths
text_entry: And as he saith, so say we all with him.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I humbly thank him, and I thank you all.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But who comes here, led by a lusty Goth?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter a Goth, leading AARON with his Child in his arms

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Renowned Lucius, from our troops I stray'd

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: To gaze upon a ruinous monastery;

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: And, as I earnestly did fix mine eye

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Upon the wasted building, suddenly

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: I heard a child cry underneath a wall.

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: I made unto the noise; when soon I heard

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: The crying babe controll'd with this discourse:

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: 'Peace, tawny slave, half me and half thy dam!

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Did not thy hue bewray whose brat thou art,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Had nature lent thee but thy mother's look,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Villain, thou mightst have been an emperor:

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: But where the bull and cow are both milk-white,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: They never do beget a coal-black calf.

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Peace, villain, peace!'--even thus he rates

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: the babe,--

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: 'For I must bear thee to a trusty Goth;

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Who, when he knows thou art the empress' babe,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Will hold thee dearly for thy mother's sake.'

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: With this, my weapon drawn, I rush'd upon him,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: Surprised him suddenly, and brought him hither,

speaker: Second Goth
text_entry: To use as you think needful of the man.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O worthy Goth, this is the incarnate devil

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That robb'd Andronicus of his good hand;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This is the pearl that pleased your empress' eye,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And here's the base fruit of his burning lust.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Say, wall-eyed slave, whither wouldst thou convey

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This growing image of thy fiend-like face?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Why dost not speak? what, deaf? not a word?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: A halter, soldiers! hang him on this tree.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And by his side his fruit of bastardy.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Touch not the boy; he is of royal blood.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Too like the sire for ever being good.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: First hang the child, that he may see it sprawl;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: A sight to vex the father's soul withal.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Get me a ladder.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: A ladder brought, which AARON is made to ascend

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Lucius, save the child,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And bear it from me to the empress.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If thou do this, I'll show thee wondrous things,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That highly may advantage thee to hear:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If thou wilt not, befall what may befall,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I'll speak no more but 'Vengeance rot you all!'

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Say on: an if it please me which thou speak'st

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Thy child shall live, and I will see it nourish'd.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: An if it please thee! why, assure thee, Lucius,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: 'Twill vex thy soul to hear what I shall speak;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: For I must talk of murders, rapes and massacres,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Acts of black night, abominable deeds,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Complots of mischief, treason, villanies

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ruthful to hear, yet piteously perform'd:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And this shall all be buried by my death,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Unless thou swear to me my child shall live.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Tell on thy mind; I say thy child shall live.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Swear that he shall, and then I will begin.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Who should I swear by? thou believest no god:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That granted, how canst thou believe an oath?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: What if I do not? as, indeed, I do not;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Yet, for I know thou art religious

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And hast a thing within thee called conscience,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: With twenty popish tricks and ceremonies,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Which I have seen thee careful to observe,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Therefore I urge thy oath; for that I know

speaker: AARON
text_entry: An idiot holds his bauble for a god

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And keeps the oath which by that god he swears,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To that I'll urge him: therefore thou shalt vow

speaker: AARON
text_entry: By that same god, what god soe'er it be,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That thou adorest and hast in reverence,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To save my boy, to nourish and bring him up;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Or else I will discover nought to thee.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Even by my god I swear to thee I will.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: First know thou, I begot him on the empress.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O most insatiate and luxurious woman!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Tut, Lucius, this was but a deed of charity

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To that which thou shalt hear of me anon.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: 'Twas her two sons that murder'd Bassianus;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: They cut thy sister's tongue and ravish'd her

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And cut her hands and trimm'd her as thou saw'st.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O detestable villain! call'st thou that trimming?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Why, she was wash'd and cut and trimm'd, and 'twas

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Trim sport for them that had the doing of it.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O barbarous, beastly villains, like thyself!

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Indeed, I was their tutor to instruct them:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That codding spirit had they from their mother,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As sure a card as ever won the set;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That bloody mind, I think, they learn'd of me,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As true a dog as ever fought at head.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Well, let my deeds be witness of my worth.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I train'd thy brethren to that guileful hole

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Where the dead corpse of Bassianus lay:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I wrote the letter that thy father found

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And hid the gold within the letter mention'd,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Confederate with the queen and her two sons:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And what not done, that thou hast cause to rue,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Wherein I had no stroke of mischief in it?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I play'd the cheater for thy father's hand,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And, when I had it, drew myself apart

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And almost broke my heart with extreme laughter:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I pry'd me through the crevice of a wall

speaker: AARON
text_entry: When, for his hand, he had his two sons' heads;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Beheld his tears, and laugh'd so heartily,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: That both mine eyes were rainy like to his :

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And when I told the empress of this sport,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: She swooned almost at my pleasing tale,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And for my tidings gave me twenty kisses.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: What, canst thou say all this, and never blush?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ay, like a black dog, as the saying is.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Art thou not sorry for these heinous deeds?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ay, that I had not done a thousand more.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Even now I curse the day--and yet, I think,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Few come within the compass of my curse,--

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Wherein I did not some notorious ill,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As kill a man, or else devise his death,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ravish a maid, or plot the way to do it,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Accuse some innocent and forswear myself,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Set deadly enmity between two friends,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Make poor men's cattle break their necks;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Set fire on barns and hay-stacks in the night,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And bid the owners quench them with their tears.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Oft have I digg'd up dead men from their graves,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And set them upright at their dear friends' doors,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Even when their sorrows almost were forgot;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And on their skins, as on the bark of trees,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Have with my knife carved in Roman letters,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: 'Let not your sorrow die, though I am dead.'

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Tut, I have done a thousand dreadful things

speaker: AARON
text_entry: As willingly as one would kill a fly,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And nothing grieves me heartily indeed

speaker: AARON
text_entry: But that I cannot do ten thousand more.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Bring down the devil; for he must not die

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: So sweet a death as hanging presently.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If there be devils, would I were a devil,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: To live and burn in everlasting fire,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: So I might have your company in hell,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: But to torment you with my bitter tongue!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sirs, stop his mouth, and let him speak no more.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter a Goth

speaker: Third Goth
text_entry: My lord, there is a messenger from Rome

speaker: Third Goth
text_entry: Desires to be admitted to your presence.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let him come near.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter AEMILIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Welcome, AEmilius what's the news from Rome?

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Lord Lucius, and you princes of the Goths,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: The Roman emperor greets you all by me;

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: And, for he understands you are in arms,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: He craves a parley at your father's house,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Willing you to demand your hostages,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: And they shall be immediately deliver'd.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: What says our general?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: AEmilius, let the emperor give his pledges

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Unto my father and my uncle Marcus,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And we will come. March away.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. Rome. Before TITUS's house.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, and CHIRON, disguised

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Thus, in this strange and sad habiliment,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I will encounter with Andronicus,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And say I am Revenge, sent from below

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To join with him and right his heinous wrongs.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Knock at his study, where, they say, he keeps,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To ruminate strange plots of dire revenge;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Tell him Revenge is come to join with him,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And work confusion on his enemies.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: They knock

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Enter TITUS, above

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Who doth molest my contemplation?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is it your trick to make me ope the door,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That so my sad decrees may fly away,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And all my study be to no effect?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You are deceived: for what I mean to do

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: See here in bloody lines I have set down;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And what is written shall be executed.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Titus, I am come to talk with thee.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: No, not a word; how can I grace my talk,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Wanting a hand to give it action?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thou hast the odds of me; therefore no more.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: If thou didst know me, thou wouldest talk with me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I am not mad; I know thee well enough:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Witness this wretched stump, witness these crimson lines;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Witness these trenches made by grief and care,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Witness the tiring day and heavy night;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Witness all sorrow, that I know thee well

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For our proud empress, mighty Tamora:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Is not thy coming for my other hand?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Know, thou sad man, I am not Tamora;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: She is thy enemy, and I thy friend:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I am Revenge: sent from the infernal kingdom,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To ease the gnawing vulture of thy mind,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: By working wreakful vengeance on thy foes.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Come down, and welcome me to this world's light;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Confer with me of murder and of death:

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: There's not a hollow cave or lurking-place,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: No vast obscurity or misty vale,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Where bloody murder or detested rape

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Can couch for fear, but I will find them out;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And in their ears tell them my dreadful name,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Revenge, which makes the foul offender quake.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Art thou Revenge? and art thou sent to me,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To be a torment to mine enemies?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I am; therefore come down, and welcome me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Do me some service, ere I come to thee.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lo, by thy side where Rape and Murder stands;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now give me some surance that thou art Revenge,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Stab them, or tear them on thy chariot-wheels;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And then I'll come and be thy waggoner,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And whirl along with thee about the globe.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Provide thee two proper palfreys, black as jet,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To hale thy vengeful waggon swift away,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And find out murderers in their guilty caves:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And when thy car is loaden with their heads,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I will dismount, and by the waggon-wheel

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Trot, like a servile footman, all day long,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Even from Hyperion's rising in the east

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Until his very downfall in the sea:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And day by day I'll do this heavy task,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: So thou destroy Rapine and Murder there.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: These are my ministers, and come with me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Are these thy ministers? what are they call'd?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Rapine and Murder; therefore called so,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Cause they take vengeance of such kind of men.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Good Lord, how like the empress' sons they are!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And you, the empress! but we worldly men

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Have miserable, mad, mistaking eyes.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O sweet Revenge, now do I come to thee;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, if one arm's embracement will content thee,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I will embrace thee in it by and by.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exit above

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: This closing with him fits his lunacy

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Whate'er I forge to feed his brain-sick fits,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Do you uphold and maintain in your speeches,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: For now he firmly takes me for Revenge;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, being credulous in this mad thought,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I'll make him send for Lucius his son;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And, whilst I at a banquet hold him sure,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I'll find some cunning practise out of hand,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To scatter and disperse the giddy Goths,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Or, at the least, make them his enemies.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: See, here he comes, and I must ply my theme.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Enter TITUS below

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Long have I been forlorn, and all for thee:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Welcome, dread Fury, to my woful house:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rapine and Murder, you are welcome too.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: How like the empress and her sons you are!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Well are you fitted, had you but a Moor:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Could not all hell afford you such a devil?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For well I wot the empress never wags

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But in her company there is a Moor;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, would you represent our queen aright,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: It were convenient you had such a devil:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But welcome, as you are. What shall we do?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: What wouldst thou have us do, Andronicus?

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Show me a murderer, I'll deal with him.

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Show me a villain that hath done a rape,

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: And I am sent to be revenged on him.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Show me a thousand that have done thee wrong,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And I will be revenged on them all.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Look round about the wicked streets of Rome;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And when thou find'st a man that's like thyself.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Good Murder, stab him; he's a murderer.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Go thou with him; and when it is thy hap

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To find another that is like to thee,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Good Rapine, stab him; he's a ravisher.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Go thou with them; and in the emperor's court

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: There is a queen, attended by a Moor;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Well mayst thou know her by thy own proportion,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: for up and down she doth resemble thee:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I pray thee, do on them some violent death;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They have been violent to me and mine.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Well hast thou lesson'd us; this shall we do.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: But would it please thee, good Andronicus,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To send for Lucius, thy thrice-valiant son,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Who leads towards Rome a band of warlike Goths,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And bid him come and banquet at thy house;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: When he is here, even at thy solemn feast,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: I will bring in the empress and her sons,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: The emperor himself and all thy foes;

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And at thy mercy shalt they stoop and kneel,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And on them shalt thou ease thy angry heart.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: What says Andronicus to this device?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Marcus, my brother! 'tis sad Titus calls.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter MARCUS

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Go, gentle Marcus, to thy nephew Lucius;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thou shalt inquire him out among the Goths:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Bid him repair to me, and bring with him

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Some of the chiefest princes of the Goths;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Bid him encamp his soldiers where they are:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tell him the emperor and the empress too

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Feast at my house, and he shall feast with them.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This do thou for my love; and so let him,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As he regards his aged father's life.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This will I do, and soon return again.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Now will I hence about thy business,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And take my ministers along with me.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Nay, nay, let Rape and Murder stay with me;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or else I'll call my brother back again,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And cleave to no revenge but Lucius.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: [Aside to her sons]  What say you, boys? will you

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: bide with him,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Whiles I go tell my lord the emperor

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: How I have govern'd our determined jest?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Yield to his humour, smooth and speak him fair,

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: And tarry with him till I turn again.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: [Aside]  I know them all, though they suppose me mad,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And will o'erreach them in their own devices:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A pair of cursed hell-hounds and their dam!

speaker: DEMETRIUS
text_entry: Madam, depart at pleasure; leave us here.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Farewell, Andronicus: Revenge now goes

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: To lay a complot to betray thy foes.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I know thou dost; and, sweet Revenge, farewell.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exit TAMORA

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Tell us, old man, how shall we be employ'd?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tut, I have work enough for you to do.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Publius, come hither, Caius, and Valentine!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter PUBLIUS and others

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: What is your will?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Know you these two?

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: The empress' sons, I take them, Chiron and Demetrius.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Fie, Publius, fie! thou art too much deceived;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The one is Murder, Rape is the other's name;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And therefore bind them, gentle Publius.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Caius and Valentine, lay hands on them.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Oft have you heard me wish for such an hour,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And now I find it; therefore bind them sure,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And stop their mouths, if they begin to cry.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: PUBLIUS,  and c. lay hold on CHIRON and DEMETRIUS

speaker: CHIRON
text_entry: Villains, forbear! we are the empress' sons.

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: And therefore do we what we are commanded.

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Stop close their mouths, let them not speak a word.

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Is he sure bound? look that you bind them fast.

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Re-enter TITUS, with LAVINIA; he bearing a knife, and she a basin

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, come, Lavinia; look, thy foes are bound.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Sirs, stop their mouths, let them not speak to me;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But let them hear what fearful words I utter.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O villains, Chiron and Demetrius!

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here stands the spring whom you have stain'd with mud,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This goodly summer with your winter mix'd.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You kill'd her husband, and for that vile fault

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Two of her brothers were condemn'd to death,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My hand cut off and made a merry jest;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Both her sweet hands, her tongue, and that more dear

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Than hands or tongue, her spotless chastity,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Inhuman traitors, you constrain'd and forced.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: What would you say, if I should let you speak?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Villains, for shame you could not beg for grace.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hark, wretches! how I mean to martyr you.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This one hand yet is left to cut your throats,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whilst that Lavinia 'tween her stumps doth hold

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The basin that receives your guilty blood.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You know your mother means to feast with me,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And calls herself Revenge, and thinks me mad:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hark, villains! I will grind your bones to dust

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And with your blood and it I'll make a paste,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And of the paste a coffin I will rear

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And make two pasties of your shameful heads,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And bid that strumpet, your unhallow'd dam,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Like to the earth swallow her own increase.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This is the feast that I have bid her to,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And this the banquet she shall surfeit on;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For worse than Philomel you used my daughter,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And worse than Progne I will be revenged:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And now prepare your throats. Lavinia, come,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: He cuts their throats

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Receive the blood: and when that they are dead,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Let me go grind their bones to powder small

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And with this hateful liquor temper it;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And in that paste let their vile heads be baked.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Come, come, be every one officious

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To make this banquet; which I wish may prove

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: More stern and bloody than the Centaurs' feast.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: So, now bring them in, for I'll play the cook,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And see them ready 'gainst their mother comes.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt, bearing the dead bodies

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: SCENE III. Court of TITUS's house. A banquet set out.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS, MARCUS, and Goths, with AARON prisoner

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Uncle Marcus, since it is my father's mind

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That I repair to Rome, I am content.

speaker: First Goth
text_entry: And ours with thine, befall what fortune will.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Good uncle, take you in this barbarous Moor,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This ravenous tiger, this accursed devil;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Let him receive no sustenance, fetter him

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Till he be brought unto the empress' face,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For testimony of her foul proceedings:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And see the ambush of our friends be strong;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I fear the emperor means no good to us.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Some devil whisper curses in mine ear,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: And prompt me, that my tongue may utter forth

speaker: AARON
text_entry: The venomous malice of my swelling heart!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Away, inhuman dog! unhallow'd slave!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sirs, help our uncle to convey him in.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exeunt Goths, with AARON. Flourish within

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The trumpets show the emperor is at hand.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter SATURNINUS and TAMORA, with AEMILIUS, Tribunes, Senators, and others

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What, hath the firmament more suns than one?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: What boots it thee to call thyself a sun?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Rome's emperor, and nephew, break the parle;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These quarrels must be quietly debated.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The feast is ready, which the careful Titus

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Hath ordain'd to an honourable end,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For peace, for love, for league, and good to Rome:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Please you, therefore, draw nigh, and take your places.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Marcus, we will.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Hautboys sound. The Company sit down at table

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Enter TITUS dressed like a Cook, LAVINIA veiled,  Young LUCIUS, and others. TITUS places the dishes on the table

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Welcome, my gracious lord; welcome, dread queen;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Welcome, ye warlike Goths; welcome, Lucius;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And welcome, all: although the cheer be poor,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Twill fill your stomachs; please you eat of it.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Why art thou thus attired, Andronicus?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Because I would be sure to have all well,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To entertain your highness and your empress.

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: We are beholding to you, good Andronicus.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: An if your highness knew my heart, you were.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My lord the emperor, resolve me this:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Was it well done of rash Virginius

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To slay his daughter with his own right hand,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Because she was enforced, stain'd, and deflower'd?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: It was, Andronicus.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Your reason, mighty lord?

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Because the girl should not survive her shame,

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: And by her presence still renew his sorrows.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A reason mighty, strong, and effectual;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: A pattern, precedent, and lively warrant,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: For me, most wretched, to perform the like.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Die, die, Lavinia, and thy shame with thee;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kills LAVINIA

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, with thy shame, thy father's sorrow die!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What hast thou done, unnatural and unkind?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kill'd her, for whom my tears have made me blind.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: I am as woful as Virginius was,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And have a thousand times more cause than he

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To do this outrage: and it now is done.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: What, was she ravish'd? tell who did the deed.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will't please you eat? will't please your

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: highness feed?

speaker: TAMORA
text_entry: Why hast thou slain thine only daughter thus?

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Not I; 'twas Chiron and Demetrius:

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: They ravish'd her, and cut away her tongue;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And they, 'twas they, that did her all this wrong.

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Go fetch them hither to us presently.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Why, there they are both, baked in that pie;

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Whereof their mother daintily hath fed,

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Eating the flesh that she herself hath bred.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: 'Tis true, 'tis true; witness my knife's sharp point.

speaker: TITUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Kills TAMORA

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Die, frantic wretch, for this accursed deed!

speaker: SATURNINUS
text_entry: Kills TITUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Can the son's eye behold his father bleed?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: There's meed for meed, death for a deadly deed!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Kills SATURNINUS. A great tumult. LUCIUS, MARCUS, and others go up into the balcony

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: You sad-faced men, people and sons of Rome,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: By uproar sever'd, like a flight of fowl

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Scatter'd by winds and high tempestuous gusts,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O, let me teach you how to knit again

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: This scatter'd corn  into one mutual sheaf,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These broken limbs again into one body;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lest Rome herself be bane unto herself,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And she whom mighty kingdoms court'sy to,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Like a forlorn and desperate castaway,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Do shameful execution on herself.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But if my frosty signs and chaps of age,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Grave witnesses of true experience,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Cannot induce you to attend my words,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To LUCIUS

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Speak, Rome's dear friend, as erst our ancestor,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When with his solemn tongue he did discourse

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To love-sick Dido's sad attending ear

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The story of that baleful burning night

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When subtle Greeks surprised King Priam's Troy,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tell us what Sinon hath bewitch'd our ears,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or who hath brought the fatal engine in

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: That gives our Troy, our Rome, the civil wound.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: My heart is not compact of flint nor steel;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Nor can I utter all our bitter grief,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: But floods of tears will drown my oratory,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And break my utterance, even in the time

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: When it should move you to attend me most,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lending your kind commiseration.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Here is a captain, let him tell the tale;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Your hearts will throb and weep to hear him speak.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Then, noble auditory, be it known to you,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That cursed Chiron and Demetrius

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Were they that murdered our emperor's brother;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And they it were that ravished our sister:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For their fell faults our brothers were beheaded;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Our father's tears despised, and basely cozen'd

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Of that true hand that fought Rome's quarrel out,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And sent her enemies unto the grave.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Lastly, myself unkindly banished,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The gates shut on me, and turn'd weeping out,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To beg relief among Rome's enemies:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Who drown'd their enmity in my true tears.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And oped their arms to embrace me as a friend.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I am the turned forth, be it known to you,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That have preserved her welfare in my blood;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And from her bosom took the enemy's point,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sheathing the steel in my adventurous body.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Alas, you know I am no vaunter, I;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My scars can witness, dumb although they are,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That my report is just and full of truth.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But, soft! methinks I do digress too much,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Citing my worthless praise: O, pardon me;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For when no friends are by, men praise themselves.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now is my turn to speak. Behold this child:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Pointing to the Child in the arms of an Attendant

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Of this was Tamora delivered;

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The issue of an irreligious Moor,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Chief architect and plotter of these woes:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The villain is alive in Titus' house,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And as he is, to witness this is true.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now judge what cause had Titus to revenge

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: These wrongs, unspeakable, past patience,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Or more than any living man could bear.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Now you have heard the truth, what say you, Romans?

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Have we done aught amiss,--show us wherein,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And, from the place where you behold us now,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: The poor remainder of Andronici

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Will, hand in hand, all headlong cast us down.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And on the ragged stones beat forth our brains,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And make a mutual closure of our house.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Speak, Romans, speak; and if you say we shall,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Lo, hand in hand, Lucius and I will fall.

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Come, come, thou reverend man of Rome,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: And bring our emperor gently in thy hand,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Lucius our emperor; for well I know

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: The common voice do cry it shall be so.

speaker: All
text_entry: Lucius, all hail, Rome's royal emperor!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Go, go into old Titus' sorrowful house,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To Attendants

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: And hither hale that misbelieving Moor,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: To be adjudged some direful slaughtering death,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: As punishment for his most wicked life.

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Exeunt Attendants

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: LUCIUS, MARCUS, and the others descend

speaker: All
text_entry: Lucius, all hail, Rome's gracious governor!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Thanks, gentle Romans: may I govern so,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To heal Rome's harms, and wipe away her woe!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But, gentle people, give me aim awhile,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For nature puts me to a heavy task:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Stand all aloof: but, uncle, draw you near,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To shed obsequious tears upon this trunk.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: O, take this warm kiss on thy pale cold lips,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Kissing TITUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: These sorrowful drops upon thy blood-stain'd face,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The last true duties of thy noble son!

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Tear for tear, and loving kiss for kiss,

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Thy brother Marcus tenders on thy lips:

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: O were the sum of these that I should pay

speaker: MARCUS ANDRONICUS
text_entry: Countless and infinite, yet would I pay them!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Come hither, boy; come, come, and learn of us

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To melt in showers: thy grandsire loved thee well:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Many a time he danced thee on his knee,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sung thee asleep, his loving breast thy pillow:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Many a matter hath he told to thee,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Meet and agreeing with thine infancy;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: In that respect, then, like a loving child,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Shed yet some small drops from thy tender spring,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Because kind nature doth require it so:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Friends should associate friends in grief and woe:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Bid him farewell; commit him to the grave;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Do him that kindness, and take leave of him.

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: O grandsire, grandsire! even with all my heart

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Would I were dead, so you did live again!

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: O Lord, I cannot speak to him for weeping;

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: My tears will choke me, if I ope my mouth.

speaker: Young LUCIUS
text_entry: Re-enter Attendants with AARON

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: You sad Andronici, have done with woes:

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: Give sentence on this execrable wretch,

speaker: AEMILIUS
text_entry: That hath been breeder of these dire events.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Set him breast-deep in earth, and famish him;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: There let him stand, and rave, and cry for food;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: If any one relieves or pities him,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: For the offence he dies. This is our doom:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Some stay to see him fasten'd in the earth.

speaker: AARON
text_entry: O, why should wrath be mute, and fury dumb?

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I am no baby, I, that with base prayers

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I should repent the evils I have done:

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Ten thousand worse than ever yet I did

speaker: AARON
text_entry: Would I perform, if I might have my will;

speaker: AARON
text_entry: If one good deed in all my life I did,

speaker: AARON
text_entry: I do repent it from my very soul.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Some loving friends convey the emperor hence,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And give him burial in his father's grave:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My father and Lavinia shall forthwith

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Be closed in our household's monument.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: As for that heinous tiger, Tamora,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No funeral rite, nor man m mourning weeds,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No mournful bell shall ring her burial;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: But throw her forth to beasts and birds of prey:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Her life was beast-like, and devoid of pity;

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And, being so, shall have like want of pity.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: See justice done on Aaron, that damn'd Moor,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: By whom our heavy haps had their beginning:

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Then, afterwards, to order well the state,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That like events may ne'er it ruinate.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
